body:
The core problem going on here is a bit complicated but also very simple at the same time - the TLDR is that we need to ensure we are always treating our keys as str(key) when we do these lookups because `leiden` is 100% of the time going to give you the string representation of your node back as the ID - which is what gets put into the partitions dictionary.  I had no interest trying to get Python's "pass any type of node id you want of any type" thing working in Rust so I just forced everything to encode as a string, which is great when the calling graph's nodes are strings too, but apparently has some issues in auto.py where it's using the original node ID (as an `int`, in this case) as the lookup to generate our `size` dictionary, but using str(node_id) as the key it's looking up with - which isn't going to appear in the sizes dict.

We just need to be careful that any dicts we create in this process are based on a `str(node_id)` or else we'll get things like this.

There's a similar typing issue in `leiden` and `modularity` where we implicitly cast your provided graph as `str(node_id)` for you to be nice and helpful when you call leiden, return `str(node_id) -> partition_id` mappings from leiden, and then when you try to call modularity on it to see how it turned out, it explodes because the graph you provide has `int(node_id)` keys and you're trying to look up `str(node_id)` mappings.

All of this is to say that maybe the right fix is for the python wrapper to our rust native impl should capture the node type in Python, let it cast to string for Rust and Leiden to process it, then before we hand the partition dictionary back we re-cast back to the original type.  And if we purposefully kept the original -> new mapping in memory in Python, we don't even have to have a lossy "cast back", since we'd just replace the new string representation of it back with the original as it was.

And that's the short explanation.

> All of this is to say that maybe the right fix is for the python wrapper to our rust native impl should capture the node type in Python, let it cast to string for Rust and Leiden to process it, then before we hand the partition dictionary back we re-cast back to the original type. And if we purposefully kept the original -> new mapping in memory in Python, we don't even have to have a lossy "cast back", since we'd just replace the new string representation of it back with the original as it was.

Big +1 for this, since I definitely think we should allow int or other datatypes as node keys, and this seems like the cleanest/simplest way to allow this.
It would also fix up our modularity bug calculation too, because the types would be what you'd have expected coming back.  So that's probably the right approach

@bdpedigo blech - we generate the edge list that leiden requires in `utils.py` where we generate a `List[Tuple[str, str, float]]`.  That's reasonable as a utility, but I think a `Tuple[Dict[str, Any], List[Tuple[str, str, float]]]` is not really something the common person is going to want - but it is what I need to do to fix this.

So the question is whether I can just axe this from utils or not.  There's benefits to having a "given a graph give me a basic edge list" but for all I know there's like 15 different versions of that behavior already.  So I figured I'd bring it up with you and see if you have a preference for what we do; axe it from utils or give everyone the `Tuple[Dict[str, Any], List[Tuple[str, str, float]]]` return type, which... doesn't seem super useful.  Or, I guess, replicate the function and have a private leiden specific version that does that.

hmmm i guess i dont see why the conversion to edgelist needs to be exposed to the user? am i missing something?

> Or, I guess, replicate the function and have a private leiden specific version that does that.

Is this you suggesting we don't need the user to see/care about what leiden is really eating under the hood? If so I agree with that.

We only exposed it before because having a quick way to write out an edge list regardless of what your current graph is was useful for us - sure it only saves like 2 lines of code, but a penny saved is a penny earned or something.  I don't know.

Regardless, it's currently in utils, and changing it to the new way is going to make it less obviously useful, so I'd rather remove it from utils entirely rather than say "here's this wacky function that almost nobody in the world is going to care about now but I guess you can use it to turn a graph in csr matrix form into an edge list if you want as long as you throw half of the top level tuple away" just doesn't sound particularly useful
totally fine with removing it from utils, personally!

issue.title: Leiden types wrapper bugfix
issue.body:
- [ ] Does this PR add any new dependencies?
- [x] Does this PR modify any existing APIs?
   - [ ] Is the change to the API backwards compatible?
- [x] Have you built the documentation (reference and/or tutorial) and verified the generated documentation is appropriate?

#### Reference Issues/PRs

Partially fixes #738

#### What does this implement/fix? Briefly explain your changes.
When running Leiden, if your graph has `int` (or anything other than `str`) node IDs, we automatically convert them to string representations for the native leiden impl to handle.  The problem is that the node id -> partition dictionary we return uses the `str` representation as the key, which won't map up to the value you actually provided in your networkx Graph.

This definitively fixes the bug in Leiden - which was one of the issues we had in #738!

The problem is that 738 also has a bug almost the same in n2v - namely, that the nodes are converted to strings for word2vec to operate over them, then returned as string labels.  We fixed the first problem, but not the second - yet.  @nyecarr is working on a n2v refactor that will fix this, and thus fully close #738.

In the meantime, this should solve Leiden over our graphs.  ~~I just realized I also need to create a test to validate it works over matrices as well as networkx - so I'll make sure that works in a test prior to actually completing this PR.~~ This is done now

#### Any other comments?

It's unclear to me that we need a new minor release with a breaking API change if we haven't actually published a final release of 0.2.0 yet.  Our dev / prerelease versions will certainly have a breaking api change, but ... I don't think this needs to become 0.3.0?  @bdpedigo?

body: Augh this shouldn't have been closed

issue.title: Allow arbitrary types of node ids for node2vec
issue.body:
<!--
Thanks for contributing a pull request! Please ensure you have taken a look at
the contribution guidelines: https://github.com/microsoft/graspologic/blob/dev/CONTRIBUTING.md
-->

- [ ] Does this PR add any new dependencies?
- [x] Does this PR modify any existing APIs?
   - [ ] Is the change to the API backwards compatible?
- [x] Have you built the documentation (reference and/or tutorial) and verified the generated documentation is appropriate?
    - I have run the sphinx-build command specified in the makefile but I am not seeing my docstring changes reflected in the built docs -- send help.

#### Reference Issues/PRs
Fixes #738 

#### What does this implement/fix? Briefly explain your changes.
Original implementation of node2vec only truly worked if a graph's node ids were strings. Because gensim's word2vec expects strings to generate the random walks, we were getting incorrect results when passing in a graph with node ids of any type other than string. This PR will fix this issue by immediately creating a new graph that has the same exact edgelist except all node ids are remapped to a unique string. Then, before returning the embedding, we remap the results from word2vec back to the original node ids.

#### Any other comments?
N2v is used in when generating layouts so I added an additional test around layout_umap to verify both string and int node ids return as expected.
